content: We have a local group at our university exploring Lean for teaching mathematics courses. Is there a way for me to set up a private channel for our local group members?
Yup. Direct Messages lets you add in several users.
Direct messages are a bad approach, as adding a new member creates a new channel with no prior history
And has no support for threaded discussions. It's meant for a different purpose
I was yesterday-years-old when I realized there is only one group chat for every set of users.
I'm not so sure. Maybe there are two conversations between the users âˆ…\emptysetâˆ… :grinning:
If the traffic is low and you don't need arbitrarily long message history, it's also possible to set up your own Zulip organization for your university for free (cloud hosted)

You can also ask for a private channel to be created on this zulip. For specific events, this has been done in the past. (I'm not sure if there's a general policy for when this is/is not acceptable.)
Though, medium-term your own zulip is clearly useful: this zulip might be rather busy if every university decides to use it :-)

Michael Rothgang said:

your own zulip

Let me expand on that. Zulip is open source, meaning that you can even host your own server.

@Chris Wong @Jireh Loreaux Thank you. I use Discord for my other computing projects. It is quite good. My purpose here is to also bring my colleagues and students interested in Lean into this friendly community. So it would be perfect to have them use this lean prover.zulipchat for both our local (private) discussion and for broader Lean questions.
@Sergey Cherkis I sent you a private message about the creation of a channel.
Sergey Cherkis has marked this topic as resolved.
